{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3553105,"name":"Sam Bowling","username":"SBowling4","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/258eb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-10T18:53:31.099Z","cooked":"

This year, our team (1810) built a telescoping arm with a double-axis wrist on the top. We’ve had a lot of issues programming one of the axis on the wrist, the one we called roll.

The main issues we’ve had are with it not correctly moving to setpoints, and with oscillations. There’s going to be a hard stop installed on it soon, which we had on earlier in the season but we took it off because one time (not during tuning, during drive practice) the NEO 550 that runs it pushed it full power into the hard stop, which ended up burning the NEO.

How could we go about correcting these issues?

Github
Match Video (shows issues)

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-10T18:53:31.099Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":107.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495024,"topic_slug":"wrist-pid-issues","display_username":"Sam Bowling","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CqDPOZFFf6M","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":15},{"url":"https://github.com/Team1810Robotics/2025-1810-RobotCode","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - Team1810Robotics/2025-1810-RobotCode","clicks":4},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/wrist-issues/495943","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Wrist Issues","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63523,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1810 & 9316 Co-President | FTC 23785"},"post_url":"/t/wrist-pid-issues/495024/1","custom_user_title":"FRC 1810 & 9316 Co-President | FTC 23785","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3553118,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-10T19:03:30.541Z","cooked":"

Is your code up to date? I don’t see any “wrist” subsystem

I do see and arm with the PIDs set to 0

Sounds possibly like an encoder issue, but It’s hard to tell when it’s not in person. Here’s some things I’d do:

  1. Use advantagekit to log the inputs and outputs. Yes it is a little long to set up but it’s worth it when you have an issue like you’re having now
  2. Make sure your encoder is working right. If it’s a magnetic encoder and loses contact with the magnet, it will output bad data
  3. Use your encoder to reference the motor, then use the motor’s internal encoder for feedback. This allows you to run PIDs on the motor controller, which is faster/higher update rate, and will prevent bad sensor data from affecting your wrist
  4. Use the WPILib units. I see in your arm subsystem you’re converting rotations to degrees. If you use the units library, then it can do that for you automatically. And it allows the programmer to understand exactly what every unit is

Yeah, our branches are a bit of a mess right now. Up to date code is in the Programming branch, (we have a reason for the on the nose name). Encoder is a REV through-bore encoder plugged into the DIO port on the rio.

Is there any reason you didn’t plug the encoder into the motor controller itself?

I see that on line 46 of your pitch subsystem (I think is the wrist)

github.com

Team1810Robotics/2025-1810-RobotCode/blob/8f6ee78c98b3dac8b9cfad767e1cc15b88626648/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/PitchSubsystem.java#L46


      
    
          
  1.   double position = encoder.get() - PitchConstants.ENCODER_OFFSET;
    2. 
          
  2.   double degrees = position * 360;
    3. 
          
  3.  
    4. 
          
  4.   return degrees; 
    5. 
          
  5. }
    6. 
          
  6. 
          
  7. /**
    8. 
          
  8.  * Runs the pitch motor with PID
    9. 
          
  9.  * @param setPoint Setpoint for wrist
    10. 
          
  10.  */
    11. 
          
  11. public void run(double setPoint) {
    12. 
          
  12.   if (encoder.isConnected()) {
    13. 
          
  13.     pitchMotor.set(pitchPIDController.calculate(getMeasurment(), setPoint));
    14. 
          
  14.   }
    15. 
          
  15.   else {
    16. 
          
  16.     System.out.println("Pitch Encoder Disconnected");
    17. 
          
  17.     stop();
    18. 
          
  18.     pitchMotor.disable();
    19. 
          
  19.   }
    20. 
          
  20. }
    21. 
          
  21.

You have shut off the motor if the encoder is disconnected. Do you know if that is happening?

I see you publish a bunch of stuff to network tables. If you don’t want to run AdvantageKit, at least log the networktables values

How to log the networktable to .wpiolog? Programming
Hi is there any way to log the network tables to the wpilog? If I send a lot of values to the network table is this going to impact the performance of the roborio (2) and is this going to take space in the router to driver station bandwidth (4mb)?
FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs

By default, no telemetry data is recorded (saved) on the robot. The DataLogManager class provides a convenient wrapper around the lower-level DataLog class for on-robot recording of telemetry data ...

not a coding issue per say, but I would really recommend your team find a way to mount a NEO 1.1 to control your arm instead of a 550. It will last longer due to its higher torque and doesn’t smoke when stall.

From my experience, limit the supply current on the 550 to under at least 70 amps

Make sure the encoder magnetic cannot move WRT its shaft.
My team had so much backlash in the shoulder that no amount of programming that we know how to do will fix it so we are getting a new shoulder.
It looks like kP is too large but I’m sure you tuned it the best you could. You could try a profiled PID controller either WPILib or in the motor controller.

It’s on a 5:1 90 degree gearbox. The encoder is placed on the axle the motor rotates, but it’s physically just above the NEO.
